You don't have to care about how the string is implemented here
This is part of object oriented programming, you place your trust in the writer of the class that you are using, and you no longer have to care about exactly how it is implemented
It's not c where you have to think, ok its a const char* and its got an end with a null terminator and I've got to be careful and not call [?] on something that doesn't have a null terminal and -nah
Don't worry about how the string is implemented just believe that the string works.

Then you just have to worry about the stuff that you are in charge of and the string class will handle that automatically by virtue of having properly defined constructors, copy constructors, assignment operators, destructors, etc.
